DOC.HEAD: Consumer Spending Rose Sharply in November on Higher Incomes
Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The report ...,' to CORRECT last high from March to April. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Consumer spending rebounded 0.7 percent in November from its sharp fall a month earlier, the government reported Thursday, and analysts said it continues to be one of the bright spots in a slowing economy. ``It suggests that while we have some weak areas in the economy, particularly in the manufacturing sector, that the consumer has not turned off completely,'' said David Jones, an economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. in New York. The Commerce Department also reported an 0.8 percent increase in personal incomes in November, but some analysts questioned whether income growth will soon begin to weaken and thus cause a decline in spending. The report said consumer spending rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate to $3.54 trillion, a 0.7 percent increase and the steepest gain since a 1 percent jump last April. The advance was a rebound from a 0.2 percent decline in October, which was the first decrease since a 0.1 percent dip in September 1988 and the largest drop since a 1.4 percent fall in January 1987. Consumer spending, which has been a major factor for the economic growth during the first nine months of the year, is watched closely as a barometer of economic health because it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. Commerce reported last week that retail sales rose 0.8 percent in November, a rebound from a 1.3 percent decrease in October. Analysts said it reflected the start of the Christmas buying season the weekend after Thanksgiving. As measured by the gross national product, the economy grew at a 3 percent rate in the third quarter after gains of 3.7 percent in the first and 2.5 percent in the second, but analysts expect a sharp decline in the three-month period ending Dec. 31. Jones said prospects are good for continued consumer spending, ``particularly in non-durables such as apparel, and in the services area ... because consumers are still basically optimistic and have income growth to support that optimism.'' Personal incomes in November totaled $4.54 trillion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, following a similar 0.8 percent gain to $4.50 trillion in October. It was the largest increase since a 1 percent gain last March. But Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group, a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., forecasting group, said there were a number of factors that could lead to decreased spending. ``The negatives are the high debt loads,'' he said. ``People now are getting more concerned about the future. You're seeing more layoffs and, particularly for durables, the pent-up demand we had in the earlier '80s has just been used up. People just don't have the same needs.'' The $26.2 billion increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, contrasted to a $6.3 billion decrease in October. Purchases of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ rose $1.9 billion, while purchases of non-durable goods jumped $12.4 billion. Spending on services increased $11.9 billion. The November report showed that Americans' incomes after taxes rose 0.9 percent, up from October's 0.8 percent gain. Americans' savings rate _ savings as a percent of disposable income _ rose to 6.1 percent, up from October's 5.7 percent rate. The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, edged up $1.7 billion in November following a $29.4 billion gain in October. Payrolls at manufacturing companies, hit hardest by the Federal Reserve's high-interest polices, fell $4.9 billion, after an October advance of $6.3 billion.
